message: Ah yeah, that's true.
would be awesome to someday (when free time exists) to move the whitespace cropping and overlay stuff from shelfworthy in there
@bmelton At first glance, difference is that IK can strap onto an existing ImageFIeld, and it allows for an unlimited amount of specs to be used for resizing. Example: https://gist.github.com/819905
That would be spectacular. :D
Out of curiosity, what in particular do you dislike about sorl.thumbnail?

wow, I always end up doing that stuff myself
pinging @carljm :)  he's smarter than I am

@chrisdrackett yeah
I need to look at IK in more detail
and I've always been impressed by it :D

IK is pretty cool

especially for future projects
yeah, things are looking good right now
vs. what we have in shelfworthy where an item model has definitions for the different images sizes
I have a client project coming up soon that will have some image and template stuff
@bryan sure

Been using django-imagekit (https://bitbucket.org/jdriscoll/django-imagekit/overview) in my apps for a while now, but unfortunately it's fallen into disrepair. What are you guys using for image processing? I'd like to find something like django-imagekit (and less like say, sorl.thumbnail).
harmony app does something like this
I've had good luck with django-stdimage, but having not used imagekit, I'm not 100% sure how well it fares.  http://code.google.com/p/django-stdimage/

@niran I never liked the API for it. ImageKit's API just threw on an extra attribute to whatever ImageField you attached it to, so it was as easy as calling {{ photo.spec.url }} as opposed to the {% thumbnail %}{% endthumbnail %} stuff.
@chrisdrackett Yeah, it sort of fails with S3, there are some fixes posted. Was wondering if I should just fork and go.
@chrisdrackett Should I fork an invite you in?
"fork an invite you in"
wut
:D
I might be willing to help out
I need to look over shelfworthy's current image code
but I can see how this would be really nice
I really like the idea of image specs
@bryan I might take this on then :D
@chrisdrackett Definitely, it just hasn't been updated in 8 months. :[
although the end results are beautfiul
and being able to use them on the fly in templates
I'm not sure what @alex is "wut"ing
hm, no thumbnail
o_O?
on github of course!
i think...

I have a replacement for it that uses PyMagick for png/jpeg/etc. I'd open source it, but right now I'm struggling to get animated thumbnails to be resized while preserving the animation. Anyone know a solution for that?

@bmelton Personally, I didn't like the API for Sorl thumbnails. I wanted something declarative because I only create images when an upload is made. And I definitely didn't want the overhead of Redis just to have images dynamically created by templates (its a feature that's useful for a site where every image may have varying sizes, but not for an image gallery where all the sizes will be created eventually)

Since I work with a designer who's good with templates but doesn't do Python code, it lets us divide responsibilities better. He can mess with layouts, including thumbnail sizes for user-uploaded images, without having to get me involved at all.
@alex @chrisdrackett I'm not sure something more dynamic would be workable for shw because of the fixed-size overlays.
At least, that's why I didn't suggest using something like sorl-thumbnail or imagekit for those thumbs.
I like that imagekit has processors for things like watermarks even though I don't use them very often.  Does sorl-thumbnail have anything like that?
i should probably play around with sorl-thumbnail just to see what other options are available.
@newman honestly I don't know, I've never used or looked for that feature.
For my own projects I use sorl-thumbnail. I really like the API, specifically that it is templater-oriented and doesn't require predefined sizes in Python code.
I've been using easy-thumbnails (the sorl-thumbnail successor), but an alternative project called sore-thumb has caught my eye
I'll probably just end up using sore-thumb from now on
@carljm yeah, thats true. Although it might be cool to add some features like whitespace removing, masks and overlays to something like this
I need to check out sorl-thumbnail too
@SmileyChris easy-thumbnails is another option as well. https://github.com/SmileyChris/easy-thumbnails
the thing I really like about IK (and I haven't actually *used* it yet) is that its code based
and as @bryan said, the template impact is minimal
I'm currently using imagekit too and really like it. If you guys are going with that fork, I'll be happy to help.
@rochacon Thank you! It lives here: https://github.com/bryanveloso/django-specops :]
@bryan Nice, watching it... =D
Looks like we got the keys to django-imagekit, so I'm getting rid of my fork and you can follow it here: https://github.com/jdriscoll/django-imagekit
@bryan Cool would really like to see it going forward. I 'm playing with the photologue 3.x branch that's using it

I don't suppose any of these app deal use ImageMagick (versus PIL)? My very first django project dealt with openexr (hdr) images that I needed to thumbnail. At the time it looked like my best bet was "from scratch", so that's what I did. It was kind of painful.
@kaysackey I'd suggest that waiting for animated thumbnails was kind of overkill ...
@theomn Sorl-Thumbnails uses PgMagick which relies on the GraphicsMagick++ fork of ImageMagick

@holdenweb Oh, animated thumbs works but its using  a PIL module ( https://github.com/9cloud/Kes-Thumbnails/blob/master/images2gif.py ), but it doesn't coalesce the gif data so it leads to some interesting errors. Imagemagick allows for image coalescing, but PgMagick doesn't yet support that.

@theomn https://github.com/acdha/NativeImaging/ is my rudimentary attempt to build a PIL-like interface over other libraries. Currently has basic (thumbnailing, conversion) via GraphicsMagick or AWARE (which we needed for good JP2 performance)
FYI - updated djangopackages to point to the newly invigorated GitHub repo
@ptone Cool!
@ptone Thank you so much!
yes, thanks @ptone. Was just thinking about the fact that that needed updating.
